query: Y Combinator AI companies 2025 2026 recent batches
answer: Y Combinator's 2025 batch included 150+ startups, with AI dominating sectors. In 2026, AI remains central to innovation. Many startups focus on B2B tools and infrastructure.

results.title: Y Combinator's Latest 150+ Startups in FinTech, Healthcare, AI
results.content:
Meet Y Combinator's latest batch of startups (F25)
Ahead of YC's demo day this Wednesday, we’ve just published the full market map of 150+ new startups building across 👇
1. FinTech
2. Marketing & Sales
3. Healthcare
4. Hardware, Drones & Robotics
5. AI Employees
6. Product
7. Defense
8. Build AI Agents
9. Research
10. Machine Learning
11. Voice
12. Coding & Dev Tools
13. Consumer Social & Commerce
14. Privacy & Security
15. HR
16. Compliance & Legal
17. Computer Vision
18. Data
19. Video
20. Collaboration & Productivity
21. Construction & Real Estate
What do we know so far about the startups?
1. 13% of this batch are building dev tools, compared to 30% in the previous batch.
2. Notable sectors include: FinTech, Healthcare, Marketing & Sales, Hardware & Robotics as well as AI Employees. [...] 🚀 Y Combinator's Fall 2025 Request for Startups is here! If you missed it, they're dropping updates every 3 months now.
🔥 What's in this fresh lineup? Just 6 hot topics:
1️⃣ Retraining Workers for the AI Economy 
2️⃣ Video Generation as a Primitive 
3️⃣ The First 10-person, $100B Company 
4️⃣ Infrastructure for Multi-Agent Systems 
5️⃣ AI Native Enterprise Software 
6️⃣ Using LLMs Instead of Government Consulting 
🧐 How does this differ from past lists? 
🔹 Shortest list yet, with fewer topics! 
🔹 Less focus on infrastructure—no data centers or inference this time. 
🔹 No consumer requests except for video generation (where the enterprise market is still king). 
🔹 Feels more like a continuation than a revolution—but still intriguing! [...] 150+ startups pitched at Y Combinator’s F25 Demo Day last week.
Here’s what the batch looks like.
The batch is heavily B2B.
Roughly two-thirds of all companies are building infrastructure, tools, or automation for other businesses — not consumers.
AI is now the default.
52 percent of startups explicitly reference AI in their tagline.
Founders are younger than ever.
A noticeable share are 18–25, skipping college and building full-time.
Sector distribution by startup count:
• 21 in coding and developer tools
• 13 in healthcare
• 13 in fintech
• 12 in marketing and sales
• 11 building AI employees
• 11 in hardware, drones, and robotics
• 7 in consumer social and commerce
• 7 in construction and real estate
• 7 in privacy and security
• 7 focused on video
• 7 data companies

results.title: The Top Startups To Watch From Y Combinator's Fall 2025 Batch
results.content:
For some, the shift is one of pace and intensity. “YC compresses months of growth into weeks,” said Aman Mishra, Co-founder & CEO at Unsiloed AI. “The real magic is momentum — you leave with a completely new sense of how fast ‘fast’ can be.” Others point to the ruthless clarity the environment demands. As Jun Kim described it, “The environment forces clarity through competition. Everything moves faster, focus gets sharper, and suddenly everything you do is leveraged 10x.” [...] ByDasha Shunina,

Contributor.

Origami Unicron

Since 2005, Y Combinator has backed over 5,000 companies that have a combined valuation of over $800 billion. The Fall 2025 batch features around 150 startups spanning a diverse range of industries — yet one clear trend stands out: the dominance of B2B software, representing nearly two-thirds of the cohort — a clear signal that this generation of founders is focused on building infrastructure and tools that power other businesses. Beyond B2B, the batch includes consumer startups, healthcare, industrials, in fintech, real estate, reflecting YC’s ongoing evolution toward practical, revenue-driven innovation. These are founders building the rails for the AI era — not just riding it.

## The Builders [...] Lightberry’s team grew up on sci-fi robots like R2-D2 and WALL·E and decided to bring them to life. “We want robots to be coworkers and companions, not just tools,” founders Ali Attar and Stephan Koenigstorfer said.  
  
Lemma’s founders, Jerry Zhang and Cole Gawin, have been best friends and co-builders since freshman year, both full-ride USC students obsessed with agent systems. They put it straight: “We’re young, scrappy, and will do whatever it takes to make things work.”

results.title: Y Combinator 2025: How AI is Reshaping Startups and Markets
results.content:
Key Insight : Acquisitions remain the dominant exit strategy, reinforcing the idea that major tech companies prefer acquiring innovation rather than building it from scratch. This trend also reflects investor confidence in startups that demonstrate clear market traction. For example, Dylan Field and Jared Friedman have both emphasized the importance of network effects in scaling software companies.

# AI Boom: The Backbone of Modern Startups

analysis of top industry tags
ai companies accepted to ycombinator

## A. AI’s Unstoppable Rise

AI-focused startups grew from 871 in 2024 to 1,140 in 2025 , accounting for 53% of all newly created YC startups . AI is now embedded across diverse domains: [...] ## B. AI Dominance

AI is the standout sector, with 33 out of 46 new startups in 2025 tagging “artificial-intelligence.”

#### 

## C. Market Maturity

The ecosystem shows signs of maturing, with stabilization in active companies despite increased competition.

Key Insight : Success now depends on deeper, more impactful innovation—not just being part of the YC network. Office Hours and mentorship programs continue to play a crucial role in guiding fast-growing YC startups .

# Conclusion

YC continues to be a driving force in the startup world, but the rapid expansion of past years has given way to a more measured, competitive landscape.

## Key Takeaways :

AI is no longer a trend; it’s the foundation upon which startups are built. [...] datahut logo.png

# Y Combinator 2025: How AI is Reshaping Startups and Markets

Writer: Aarathi J

Updated: May 29, 2025

Y Combinator 2025: How AI is Reshaping Startups and Markets

In 2025, over 72% of new startups in Y Combinator are powered by artificial intelligence , signaling a seismic shift in how technology is driving innovation across industries. From automating mundane tasks to revolutionizing entire sectors, AI has moved beyond being a buzzword—it’s now the backbone of modern entrepreneurship.

results.title: Explore the Latest Y Combinator Companies List: Top Startups to ...
results.content:
What’s neat about Replit is how they’ve integrated AI right into the coding process. Their AI coding assistant can help you write code faster, suggest fixes, and generally make the whole development experience smoother. It’s like having a helpful buddy looking over your shoulder, but one that actually knows what it’s doing.

They’ve managed to attract a huge user base, with over 2 million people using their platform. That’s a lot of coders! It shows they’re doing something right in making software development easier for everyone, from beginners to experienced pros. [...] # Explore the Latest Y Combinator Companies List: Top Startups to Watch in 2026

Modern cityscape with glowing skyscrapers and people below.

## Share This Post

Every year, Y Combinator churns out a fresh batch of promising startups. We’re looking ahead to 2026 and have compiled a list of some of the most interesting Y Combinator companies that are making waves. These companies are tackling big problems with innovative solutions, and it’s worth keeping an eye on their progress. From AI advancements to new approaches in finance and beyond, this y combinator companies list highlights the future of tech.

### Key Takeaways

## 1. Listen Labs [...] ## 10. MoonPay and more

Beyond the big names, the Y Combinator ecosystem is buzzing with innovative companies like MoonPay. Founded in 2019, MoonPay is making waves by simplifying the process of buying and selling digital assets. Think of them as the financial plumbing for cryptocurrencies and NFTs, powering the payment experience for many popular crypto wallets and marketplaces.

It’s not just about crypto, though. The YC batch is always diverse. We’re seeing companies tackle everything from AI-driven advertising with creators to automating complex software deployments. For instance, one startup is helping brands connect with real creators for AI-powered ad campaigns, while another is focused on streamlining software deployments, making life easier for businesses.

Whether you’re an investor scouting for promising startups or an entrepreneur seeking inspiration, our batch explorer makes it easy to find the information you need — all in one place.

## Why Focus on Y Combinator Companies? [...] # Discover Y Combinator Companies: Your Ultimate Batch Explorer

Y Combinator Companies have become synonymous with breakthrough innovation and startup success. If you’re looking for the latest and greatest in tech and entrepreneurship, you’ve come to the right place. On this page, not only will you find insights about Y Combinator Companies, but you’ll also discover a comprehensive list of all YC batches — each one leading to an interactive table loaded with data on every startup from that round.

## What Are Y Combinator Companies? [...] ## What Are Y Combinator Companies?

Y Combinator, one of the world’s most prestigious startup accelerators, has nurtured some of the most influential companies of our time — from Airbnb and Dropbox to Stripe. These companies are known for their innovative ideas and rapid growth. By diving into the world of Y Combinator Companies, you gain access to valuable data and trends that can inform your investment decisions, entrepreneurial journey, or market research.

results.title: Y Combinator's New “Requests for Startups” (Fall 2025): AI ... - Reddit
results.content:
2. Video Generation as a Primitive: With Google’s Veo 3 already producing near-photorealistic clips, YC thinks video is becoming a new computing primitive. They imagine AI-native TikTok, infinite gaming worlds, personalized shopping videos, even video calls with loved ones after they’re gone.

3. The First 10-person, $100B Company: Thanks to AI tools, YC believes tiny, high-agency teams (even solo founders) can now build massive companies with minimal funding. The north star metric: revenue per employee.

4. Infrastructure for Multi-Agent Systems: AI is moving from single agents to complex, distributed multi-agent workflows. YC wants infra startups that make deploying + monitoring agent fleets as easy as running a Spark job. [...] 5. AI-Native Enterprise Software: Just like Salesforce & ServiceNow rode the cloud wave, the next $10B+ enterprise companies will be AI-native, not bolt-on AI features slapped onto legacy systems.

6. LLMs vs. Government Consulting: The US spends $100B+ annually on consulting (Deloitte, Accenture, etc.). YC sees massive opportunity for startups to replace bloated gov consulting with LLM-driven solutions.

YC’s big bet: the next wave of unicorns will be AI-first at their core, not AI add-ons.

# Y Combinator’s New “Requests for Startups” (Fall 2025): AI as the Foundation, Not a Feature - i will not promote

YC just dropped their latest Requests for Startups list, and the theme is clear: the AI hype phase is over. Now it’s about building with it.

Some of the standout ideas they’re excited about:

1. Retraining Workers for the AI Economy: We talk a lot about AI talent, but we’re short on skilled trades (electricians, HVAC, welders) needed for data centers + fabs. YC wants startups building AI-powered vocational schools to retrain workers fast, using AR/VR, multimodal coaching, etc. Think “AI bootcamps” for physical trades.

results.title: Requests for Startups | Y Combinator
results.content:
Y Combinator
Y Combinator

# Requests for Startups

RFS is our tradition of sharing ideas we'd like to see founders tackle. These represent just a fraction of what we fund — if one excites you, take it as extra validation to dive in, but you don't need to work on these ideas to apply to YC.

## Fall 2025

The last few years were about proving what AI can do. Now, it's about building with it. We've put together a new list of startup ideas we're especially excited about— ideas that treat AI not as a feature, but as a foundation. They reflect where we think some of the biggest opportunities are right now.
